Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative: International Deltas Meeting: Genesis, Dynamics, Modelling, and Sustainable Development
Award.AbstractNarration:
This four-day international meeting will bring together 70 participants, including leading experts on delta processes, promising up-and-coming researchers, and graduate students, to present science and synthesize frontier states of knowledge on physical and biological processes in deltaic systems. The meeting will be in Istomino, Russia, on the shore of Lake Baikal and next to the Selenga River delta, one of the world's largest freshwater deltas. The overarching goal for this meeting is to promote discussion amongst international and multidisciplinary scientists who focus on delta research, to describe recent and ongoing scientific advancements, to pinpoint improvements needed, and to foster near-future transformative delta research.

Owing to their extraordinary natural resources and ecosystem services, river deltas have fostered the development of past and present civilizations, and today host over a half billion people. The sustainability of these coastal landscapes is far from certain, however, due to strong anthropogenic influences including sediment-supply reduction, subsidence from sub-surface fluid extraction, leveeing, and sea-level rise. This international workshop will bring together a multidisciplinary range of delta scientists to influence the delta research agenda at a critical juncture for delta inhabitants.

Participation of US scientists and students at the workshop is jointly supported by the Geomorphology and Land-use Dynamics program in the Division of Earth Sciences and the International Science and Education section of the Office of International and Integrated Activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Owing to their extraordinary natural resources and ecosystem services, river deltas have fostered the development of past and present civilizations, and today host over 500 million people. The sustainability of these coastal landscapes is far from certain, however, due to strong human influences, including the reduction of sediment supplied to deltas, subsidence from sub-surface fluid extraction, leveeing, and drowning due to sea-level rise. In light of these major issues, a four-day meeting bringing together eighty of the world’s leading experts on deltaic processes was held in July, 2014.  A multitude of science topics were discussed, in order to synthesize the frontier states of knowledge regarding processes that underlie deltaic systems.  The “International Deltas Meeting” (IDM) took place in Istomino, Russia, on the shore of Lake Baikal and next to the Selenga River delta, one of the world’s largest freshwater deltas. The meeting included scientists from nine countries, all of whom specialize in fluvial-deltaic research. The attendees use science techniques that include field observation, experimental, modeling, and theoretical science, and span specialties including delta morphology, river engineering, physical limnology, stratigraphy, ecology, and biology.  Science was shared via presentations, group discussions, and break-out sessions. Additionally, the pristine natural setting of the meeting was used as the venue for a field trip, where regional scientists described ongoing research and sustainability efforts.  The overarching goal of this meeting was to promote science amongst international and multidisciplinary researchers who specialize in deltaic research; to describe recent and ongoing scientific advancements; to pinpoint needed improvements; and to foster transformative deltas research.   

 

Deltaic landscapes have been the focus of international scientific investigations, supported by a large number of public and private funding agencies. The complex nature of deltaic systems means that there is a wide range of scientists with diverse backgrounds investigating delta dynamics. While union and society meetings have served as venues to disseminate deltaic science, session meetings are limited in terms of time, organized by specific research groups, and typically consist of narrow science focuses. The IDM blended the intellectual capacities of investigators who have a diverse range of science interests and investigative techniques. The meeting addressed basic and applied questions regarding delta evolution and function. Information sharing provided a path forward for future collaborative international deltas research, particularly regarding practices of sustainability for these threatened landscapes. The central merit of this conference was to foster in-depth discussions of multidisciplinary science research regarding river deltas. These efforts were fruitful because of the large international contingent of investigators, led by Russian scientists, who brought diverse perspectives regarding the science of fluvial deltaic systems.
